text.content: “...add a plague of rats to everything else New York faces in trying to rebound from the Covid-19 pandemic.”

text.plain_text: “...add a plague of rats to everything else New York faces in trying to rebound from the Covid-19 pandemic.”

text.content: Based on recent articles from the New York Times and general small talk around the city and surrounding areas, I sought to investigate the claims that these articles made and compare rat sighting data from 2020 to 2021. Using data from the NYC open data portal to aggregate rat sightings from each of the 5 boroughs in New York City, I found that my investigation supported the unsettling assertions that The New York Times made about our rising rodent presence.

text.plain_text: Based on recent articles from the New York Times and general small talk around the city and surrounding areas, I sought to investigate the claims that these articles made and compare rat sighting data from 2020 to 2021. Using data from the NYC open data portal to aggregate rat sightings from each of the 5 boroughs in New York City, I found that my investigation supported the unsettling assertions that The New York Times made about our rising rodent presence.

text.content: Initially, I intended to map and show the distribution of rat sightings over time, but through some initial prototyping I found the data to be too immense to map and show significance. Instead, I gravitated towards a radial stacked bar chart that would map the total quantities of rat sightings and at a glance give the viewer an immediate understanding of the total quantity over time. The dataset itself was quite detailed, giving every instance of a rat sighting that had been called in by an individual in NYC. Regardless of the specificity available, I sought to provide the overall numbers for each borough and narrow down the information that would allow us to see the number of sightings instantly. text.content: When restaurants closed, rats had to scavenge outside more. They found gutters and street-corner baskets clogged with trash because of cuts in the Sanitation Department Budget Illegal dumping increased. With most people stuck at home, so did residential waste.

text.plain_text: When restaurants closed, rats had to scavenge outside more. They found gutters and street-corner baskets clogged with trash because of cuts in the Sanitation Department Budget Illegal dumping increased. With most people stuck at home, so did residential waste.

text.content: This, among other factors, such as a wetter than normal summer season and a general warming climate, has helped rats thrive under the pandemic circumstances. Even prior to the pandemic shifting the way New York City operates, it is evidenced by NYC open data that rat sightings increase during the warmer months, as a result of both people spending more time outside as well as rats’ preference for a warmer atmosphere.

Even prior to the pandemic shifting the way New York City operates, it is evidenced by NYC open data that rat sightings increase during the warmer months, as a result of both people spending more time outside as well as rats’ preference for a warmer atmosphere.

text.content: In exploring the claims from The New York Times, I found that there is truth in the assertions that rat sightings have surged during the pandemic due to the more than unusual circumstances. In researching further, I would be interested in fleshing out the pandemic timeline a bit more and showing the data parallel to specific instances during the NYC shutdown. (For example, giving context to when the first Covid-19 case was found in New York, when construction sites were halted, when restaurants closed and slowly reopened again, etc.) I believe that this could give further insight as to why certain surges in rat sightings occurred and dropped, outside of the blanket explanation of warmer climates and city ordinances.

text.content: , an organization advocating for a more accessible web, was an exciting turning point. I’d initially imagined my project focusing on the physical aspects of accessibility, but it made a lot of sense to start looking at the accessibility of virtual spaces. Since web development has been an underlying practice of this course, this adjustment felt fitting. WebAIM not only offers written analysis of their studies, they also include summarized numerical data (as tables), distilled from raw data. Some of their surveys feature additional visualizations, i.e. pie charts, so I began to wonder how else the tables could be visualized.

text.content: This project begins a long personal journey toward advocating for accessibility through the lens of anti-ableism. As non-disabled, and toward a continued practice of becoming aware of my own ableist biases, I hope to first begin having more conversations about ableism, and particularly where it goes wrong. The origin of ableism and other oppressive ‘ism’s’ is a connection I’m particularly interested in teasing apart. Ongoing research into best practices and implementing techniques toward accessibility are both my current constraints and next mileposts. This particular iteration is certainly not accessible according to web standards, the very subject of this project, but the aim remains and future iterations will be improved, as reflections of where I am and what I've learned.

meta.title: Slim Thick, The United Curves of America

text.content: Slim Thick is an uncommon female body type that consists of a flat stomach, toned thighs, and large booties that originated from a voluptuous body form celebrated as a counterculture over five decades ago, and was eventually adopted and popularized by the Kardashian in conjunction with the rise and dominance of social media.

text.plain_text: Slim Thick is an uncommon female body type that consists of a flat stomach, toned thighs, and large booties that originated from a voluptuous body form celebrated as a counterculture over five decades ago, and was eventually adopted and popularized by the Kardashian in conjunction with the rise and dominance of social media.

text.content: I decided to dig deeper into this topic when I started to hear more and more stories about teenage girls’ obsession with Slim Thick. The idealization of the Slim Thick body is a phenomenon I attributed to the continuation of the historical male gaze and capital exploitation of the female body. It is also another example of appropriation of the black culture, all against the backdrop of the growing normality of plastic surgery and algorithmic reinforcement of social media.

text.content: The main design element is an optical illusion of the male gaze, which is composed of two silhouettes featuring Zuck-Buck-A-Lot (social media) and Dr. Butt-A-Lot (plastic surgery). The negative space between the silhouettes resembles the outline of the Slim Thick body.

text.content: The fonts were a different story. I simply took a totally different route. After some exploration, I went with the following two fonts: Futura and Moret. Futura is a Geometric sans-serif typeface designed by Paul Renner. Traditionally considered a Bauhaus font, it is a hugely influential modern typeface. Moret, however, is what I chose to use for my headings. Moret is a serif typeface designed by Jamie Chang in 2019. Heavily inspired by twentieth-century European sign painting and features flared stroke endings with a calligraphic touch.

text.content: Conspiracy theories and the belief in them have exponentially grown in the last few years and are increasingly influencing public opinion and life. Therefore, it is of great importance to analyze what we know historically about what makes certain groups more likely to subscribe to such believes and see if there are any strategies successfully employed in the past to unite people who are likely to be divided by such believes. Why do people see them so differently - for some, they are facts, and for others, simply an illusion.

text.content: Conspiracies have been a hot topic in recent years, especially since the beginning of the COVID-19 pandemic. Yet, most of the data analysis available comes from research papers, which makes it inaccessible for the general public. I drew inspiration from those papers and the desire to make such data faster and easier to explore by everyone who may be interested in it.

text.content: is a data visualization project by Yoana Kosturska which explores a dataset from a 2016 survey, collecting data on common conspiracy theories. In addition, it collects respondents' demographics metrics, such as age, gender, religion, etc. The 15 conspiracies explored relate to important facets of conspiracism and are a part of the Generic Conspiracy Beliefs (GCB) scale. Respondents can answer how much they agree or disagree with a specific prompt on a 5-point scale: from strongly disagree to strongly agree.

text.plain_text: is a data visualization project by Yoana Kosturska which explores a dataset from a 2016 survey, collecting data on common conspiracy theories. In addition, it collects respondents' demographics metrics, such as age, gender, religion, etc. The 15 conspiracies explored relate to important facets of conspiracism and are a part of the Generic Conspiracy Beliefs (GCB) scale. Respondents can answer how much they agree or disagree with a specific prompt on a 5-point scale: from strongly disagree to strongly agree.

text.content: The project visualizes the data in two ways: a general overview of each question, where users can see the total number of respondents who agree/disagree with the prompt, and a more detailed view in which users can select a certain demographic metric (eg: gender) and compare how different groups responded to the prompts. With this project I want to allow exploration of different conspiracy theories - which are more "popular" than others, or is there any pattern in the way different demographic groups respond to the 15 prompts?

With this project I want to allow exploration of different conspiracy theories - which are more "popular" than others, or is there any pattern in the way different demographic groups respond to the 15 prompts?

text.content: Next, I performed user testing, in which I presented my testing partner with alternative charts fitting the same structure of the data, but communicating it in a different way. I also tested different color schemes and user interface components, as there are several demographic metrics in the dataset, each of them separated in several subgroups.

text.plain_text: Next, I performed user testing, in which I presented my testing partner with alternative charts fitting the same structure of the data, but communicating it in a different way. I also tested different color schemes and user interface components, as there are several demographic metrics in the dataset, each of them separated in several subgroups.

text.content: During the project execution phase, I carefully considered my design choices and the user journey, since the user interface includes two step selection process with one of the selections dependent on the other. Additionally, I had to consider the way I visualize the data without misrepresenting it – some demographic groups are very well represented, and others had only a few respondents. To avoid that and enable equitable comparison, I normalized the data by representing it as percentages.

text.content: The Illusion of Alcohol is a project meant to take a closer look into the alcohol industry. I was inspired by vintage alcohol advertising posters and what they represent. The data set I used took data from every country, helping look into the culture that surrounds drinking. The parameters included how much alcohol was consumed, average annual income, suicide rates, and employment rates.

text.plain_text: The Illusion of Alcohol is a project meant to take a closer look into the alcohol industry. I was inspired by vintage alcohol advertising posters and what they represent. The data set I used took data from every country, helping look into the culture that surrounds drinking. The parameters included how much alcohol was consumed, average annual income, suicide rates, and employment rates.

text.content: I want to incorporate some ambiguity to this visualization. A lot of the data is ambiguous, especially with cultural norms and I want to be able to capture this feeling. I think that in one culture, alcohol may be seen as a treat, where some see it as a daily comfort. This dataset allows us to look into how other countries handle alcohol.

text.content: This sketch is the first iteration of my project. I wanted to include a conglomerate of bar graphs to showcase every country and their discrepancies. This evolved into the right hand side of the paper where each variable was dissected with all the countries together. After some thought I noticed that the independent variable, alcohol consumption needed to be on the y-axis.

text.content: universal. According to Social Issues Research Center many cultures perceive alcohol consumption differently. Many Mediterranean and wet cultures view alcohol as peaceful and harmonious, often leading to less alcohol related problems. Whereas, cold, temperate, dry climates such as UK and Scandinavia view alcohol as a violent and anti-social behavior, also leading to more alcohol related issues. Some cultures vary and shift with the times, but there is often a large variance.

All of these poster used are clickable images to take you to the source image found on Google Images. I did a deeper dive into Smirnoff advertising because they really caught my eye.

text.content: To me, Smirnoff has changed their advertising strategies much more significantly over time than any other brand of alcohol. I saw many ad campaigns that had interesting slogans such as, "The Effect is Shattering". This slogan was tied to many phrases such as, "Accountancy was my life until I discovered Smirnoff" and "I was the mainstay of the Public Library until I discovered Smirnoff". These posters play with the insecurities of most people. The idea that "no one wants to be lame or a nerd". Smirnoff is selling you suaveness and a new more appealing lifestyle.

text.content: This was such an interesting project where, for the first time, I was questioning data collection and ethics around evictions and homelessness. I wanted to emphasize that behind each data point is a person or family at-risk of homelessness, and to change the perception of what the homeless population could look like. Visualizing “missing” data was really challenging within the given time frame. If I were to take next steps, it would be to collect and visualize the “missing” data on unlawful detainer lawsuits and sheriff’s evictions, and to do further analysis.

text.content: I brainstormed the idea based on Georges Seurat's painting. I was curious about the colors he chose and the position he applied on the canvas. How can it become an illusion to deceive our eyes? It would be interesting to get colors from his paintings and find patterns, rules, or insights that I can reinterpret with a new form. To enlarge the scope, I wanted to compare the colors he used with the other post-impressionist artists in the same period.

text.content: Since the dataset was really dirty, I used Python to perform data pre-processing. Through the process, I was able to experience the administrative violence Keyes mentioned in their article. Due to the nature of the spreadsheet, there are way too many unique values in one category and I had to categorize them manually. It was easy for questions like education levels but difficult for races, genders, or sexualities.

Through the process, I was able to experience the administrative violence Keyes mentioned in their article. text.content: For instance, I was forced to categorize everyone who did not fit into binary gender into "non-binary" otherwise I wouldn't be able to color-code it. I was also forced to categorize a lot of white or white-passing people into the section "White", and a great majority of people into "mixed as it refers to both mixed-race or mixed-ethnicity.
